summary.p: A syllabary and a grammar of the Malayalam language entitled Grammaire de la Langue Malabare on a sheet of paper pasted on the front guard leaf.
The syllabary (U1b) is not entirely covered by Gallica set of images. See further images on Didomena, here.
The work is not divided in numbered chapters. However nine sections can be identified on the basis of titles and arguments, as listed below:

list.item: Regles Generalles pour les Noms. Nouns are inflected into five declensions (pp. 1-11).
Pronoms, i.e. personnels, possessifs, demonstatifs, relatifs, interrogatifs, indefinis, responsifs, affirmatifs et negatifs (pp. 12-22).
Noms des Nombres, i.e. cardinal, adverbe (pp. 23-28). This section also includes: Grand Livret de Multiplication (pp. 29-41); Quarré de Pythagore, en Chiffres Mallabars (p. 42).

Conjugaison des Verbes (pp. 49-91). Apart from moods and tenses (i.e. indicatif, subjonctif, optatif, infinitif, gerundif, participe, conditionnel, imperatif, supin, présent, preterit imparfait, preterit parfait, passé eloigné, passé anterieur, plus que parfait, futur, passé avenir), this section also includes: verbes passifs, verbe personnel, verbes effectifs et mandatifs, verbes deffectifs affirmatifs, verbes deffectifs negatifs, particules qui rendent les verbes affirmatifs negatifs, verbes de l'Elegance Mallabarre. The section on verbs ends with Maniere d'user des Verbes, et quand on doit S'en servir (pp. 92-96).
Propositions (i.e. de lieu, de tems, de maniere, qui gouvernent le genitif, le datif, l'accusatif, etc.) (pp. 96-102).
Syntaxe ou maniere de connoitre toutes les parties d'un discours (pp. 105-114).

Title and shelfmark in black ink on a paper glued on the page (guard leaf, recto):
Grammaire de la Langue Malabare
(Picot 123)

Red circle containing an eagle and the writing Bibliothèque Impérial MSS (folio 1r). This is the stamp in use from 1852 to 1870 (cf. stamp no. 36 in Josserand and Bruno 1960, p. 282). It is placed in the middle of the page.

binding.p: Leather cover. The stiff boards and spine is covered with leather that is folded over the edges of the boards and glued down. Hence, pastedowns are applied to conceal this mechanism.

origin.origDate: No internal date. According to Petit (2009, p. 197), the work was composed by a missionary around 1700. The suggested span of time 1750-1782 is calculated on the basis of the sojourn of Bernard François Bertrand Picot, marquis de la Motte (1734-1797), in India. Picot reached the Malabar Coast in 1750 and was named General Commander of the Malabar Coast and Governor of Mahé in 1751. He returned in France in 1782 (Courcelles 1823, pp. 370-371). The linguistic features of the variety of the Portuguese language used in the manuscript would allow to date it earlier, in the first half of the 17th century.

provenance.p: Bernard Picot de la Motte. See BnF NAF 8992-9114. See also BnF BnF NAF 3659.
